ranked_diseases.explanation: Patient presents with hypertelorism and orofacial cleft, which are key features of CFND. All three reference cases with similar presentations were diagnosed with this condition. CFND is an X-linked disorder that paradoxically affects females more severely than males, which could explain the presentation in this male patient.
Characterized by hypertelorism and midline facial clefts, matching two of the three patient features. Sleep abnormalities are not typical but the core features align well with this diagnosis.
X-linked disorder presenting with hypertelorism and cleft lip/palate. Males are typically affected. Sleep disturbances can occur due to respiratory issues from laryngotracheal abnormalities.
Features hypertelorism and orofacial clefts among its characteristics. Sleep disturbances are common due to seizures and developmental delays associated with this chromosomal deletion syndrome.
Can present with cleft palate and mild hypertelorism. Sleep abnormalities may occur due to obstructive sleep apnea, which is relatively common in Kabuki syndrome.
DiGeorge/velocardiofacial syndrome can present with cleft palate and mild hypertelorism. Sleep disorders are reported in some patients, though not a primary feature.
